title: Following a User Actually Follows Another User

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
I can display a web intent page to a victim that appears to prompt them to follow one user, but actually ends up following a completely different user when they click "follow". The following is a proof of concept:

https://twitter.com/intent/follow?screen_name=twitter&screen_name=ericrtest3&user_id=113483807

This is somewhat related to the last bug I submitted (see #95217), albeit the impact is more dramatic. This can be used by malicious users such as spammers and social engineers to trick a user into following them.
vulnerability_information_html:
I can display a web intent page to a victim that appears to prompt them to follow one user, but actually ends up following a completely different user when they click "follow". The following is a proof of concept:

https://twitter.com/intent/follow?screen_name=twitter&screen_name=ericrtest3&user_id=113483807

This is somewhat related to the last bug I submitted (see #95217), albeit the impact is more dramatic. This can be used by malicious users such as spammers and social engineers to trick a user into following them.

activities.message:
Hi,

Just thought I would provide some ideas for fixes. One way to fix this bug would be to ensure that the logic is the same for choosing which param to use to display the profile, and for which user to follow after form submission. It may be that this is already the case, but that the line termination is getting filtered out and this is confusing this logic somehow. Another, perhaps simpler way to fix this would be to accept either a username or an ID as a single param and infer type.

Please let me know if you have any questions.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

Just thought I would provide some ideas for fixes. One way to fix this bug would be to ensure that the logic is the same for choosing which param to use to display the profile, and for which user to follow after form submission. It may be that this is already the case, but that the line termination is getting filtered out and this is confusing this logic somehow. Another, perhaps simpler way to fix this would be to accept either a username or an ID as a single param and infer type.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

activities.message: Correction: It was the other issue I submitted that used a line termination. Don't think that's an issue here.
activities.markdown_message: Correction: It was the other issue I submitted that used a line termination. Don't think that's an issue here.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message:
Fantastic. Glad to hear this is being looked into.

I also found that it is not required to pass in a user_id, but simply a second screen_name param. This is enough to get the form on the page to override the hidden input field that references which user is to be followed.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: Thanks for the additional information. I'll make sure we take this into account.

activities.message: Thanks again. As mentioned we’ll keep you updated as we investigate further. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.
